results.title: Marsupials: Naturally the numbat
results.creator_credit: John Shaw, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: You mean a wombat don’t you? is the usual reaction but a numbat is quite different - smaller than a cat, with a long pointed nose and a striped back. Numbats live inside hollow logs in densely wooded areas, and eat termites. Includes feeding scenes and close-ups of young numbats.

results.title: On stage
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Follows a community group in the production of a play from initial casting auditions to the final actual performance. Attempts to give, through its explanatory commentary, an overall view of typical amateur activities and a few hints on common theatrical and organisational problems.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ronald Dick, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Magic Flute
results.creator_credit: Gayle Thomas, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Lyrical animation of the magical events which occur when various children play a flute, evoking both pleasant scenes of flowers and unpleasant ones of witches and bats, according to the personality of the child. Sound film without words. (Awards: Palo Alto; Columbus)

results.title: Maestro
results.creator_credit: Mark Hughes, Martin Didsbury and Open Training and Education Network
results.brief_description: Presented by Andrea Stretton of SBS’s “The Book Show”, this video features dramatised excerpts from the novel, “Maestro”, and studio discussions with it’s author (Peter Goldsworthy) and an English teacher. Together, they explore the importance of personal response to the novel, how to establish a personal response, and how to give the ensuing personal response.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mark Hughes, Martin Didsbury and Open Training and Education Network

results.title: Night cries: a rural tragedy
results.creator_credit: Tracey Moffatt, Penny McDonald and AFTRS
results.brief_description: In the red glow of the outback an Aboriginal woman nurses her ill white mother. As we watch the old woman dying her daughter confronts the finality of death; the bitterness of memory. Shot entirely in a studio “Night cries” uses a stark set-design, a palette of colours as from a dream, and a haunting soundtrack: of bush noises, gasping breath, the wail of a dingo, to suggest a world that combines the frightening distortion of a nightmare and the painful isolation of human loss. Subtitled “a rural tragedy” the film’s portrayal of a personal agony illuminates and exposes the general horror of Australia’s race history. With Marcia Langton, Agnes Hardwick and Jimmy Little.

results.title: Night children
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The story of a case worker with a Children’s Aid Society and the children she helps. Working round the clock, the Society receives appeals of every sort. The film shows how the Society follows through in the case of a little girl found wandering alone on downtown streets at night and in other cases of children abandoned, uncared for, the victims of their environment.

results.title: Nigeria: giant in Africa
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This vivid recounting of Nigeria’s history, from pre-European times to the mid-20th century, provides dramatic background to the political maturing of Africa’s most populous country. Of particular interest is the film’s treatment of ancient African cultures as revealed in the three regions that make up the Federation of Nigeria.

results.title: Nigel Dick interview
results.brief_description:
Nigel Dick discusses how he moved from veterinary science to an advertising cadetship with the “Daily Telegraph”, finally moving into television in 1956 to Channel 9.
Dick talks about the early days of television in Australia; the influence of Arthur Warner, the Royal Commission into television in the 1950’s and it’s ensuing recommendations, the creation of “In Melbourne Tonight” based on the strength of Graeme Kennedy’s personality, and the response from other stations in creating a similar show for Bert Newton, or putting movies against “IMT” in the ratings.
He also discusses the relationship between print media and television, the origins of the channel 7 logo, and the future of television, including cable channels and digitisation.

results.title: Julie Stafford's taste of life : the video
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Dwyer, Chris Weir, AAV Australia and Martin and Rosenthal Pictures
results.brief_description: Best selling cookery writer Julie Stafford invites you to prepare a variety of mouth-watering recipes for breakfast, lunch, children’s meals and dinners for everyday and for special occasions. Julie also gives a brief outline of healthy foods to eat, shows how to choose and store them and gives an introduction to some common herbs. A weekly menu planner is included.

results.title: Juggling the elements
results.creator_credit: Katrina Sawyer, Sakshi Productions, Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Stewart Lodge and Tracey Power
results.brief_description: Tracey Power has maintained her courage, honesty and humour despite having suffered abuse and trauma at the hands of her family and the state from birth. Tracey looks different, she sometines has a shaved head and many tattoos and she is scarred from ‘slashing up’. Tracey acts differently, she doesn’t follow the social rules of behaviour. She loves trams and has the word ‘tram’ tattooed on her hand. She has a mental illness which has led her to being institutuionalised a number of times. She is both street wise and disarmingly trusting and generous. She looks very tough, yet she is very sensitive and vulnerable. She tells her story ‘in your face’ and she tells it ‘straight’ about abuse, institutions, drug addiction, mental illness, slashing up, giving up her baby for adoption and also about friendships, fun, love and hope. Tracey’s story tells us alot about living with mental illness, about being different and about surviving without losing your spirit or humanity.
